How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?
After he got home from the hospital he was angry, then for a time wonderful. Now he is depressed and hopeless again.
(Marriage Depression Selfharm)

A failed suicide attempt is commonly thought of as a cry for help; however, it can also be a serious attempt to find a permanent solution to depression, hopelessness, or other unbearable feelings. It's important to support your loved one if they are feeling this way. Feelings of hopelessness and depression, as well as previous suicide attempts, can indicate a risk for future attempts. Seeking help from a mental health professional or a hospital's emergency room is crucial in these situations. Evaluation for suicidal thoughts, intent, and plan is necessary, and if there is a danger to oneself, hospitalization may be necessary until stable. It's possible that your loved one may be suffering from Major Depressive Disorder or another depressive illness. In such cases, medication and gentle self-care can be beneficial. Don't forget to take care of yourself as well, as a suicide attempt affects not only the individual but also their loved ones. Remember to put your own oxygen mask on first so that you can provide calm and loving care and attention to your loved one.

What can I do when I can't stand being alone?
I have no real friends. I have a girlfriend who irritates me but loves me to death. I push her away and pushes me away. We're going through a breakup, and I have nobody.
(Relationships Depression)

Having time all to yourself may be necessary so you have time to reflect on your own identity and values, become more clear on what matters most to you, and with this increased self-understanding, be able to attract people who will feel like satisfying friends. Having a relationship with someone whom you push away and are pushed away, with someone who is irritating, seems to have limited benefit for each of you. Maybe you are together from fear of being alone, and being alone is exactly what you may now need in your life in order to draw more favorable people to you.

How do I let go of someone who continues to hurt me
Ive been in an on an off relationship with a this man for almost 3 years. Even though I care about him, he continues to hurt me. He and his wife were separated when we met. Now he's going through a really difficult divorce from her and is taking it really hard. I want to end this relationship, but I don't feel like I can. How can I let go?
(Relationship Dissolution )

Hello and thank you for your question. Ending relationships is tough, isn't it? Sometimes it's tough even when we are 100% sure that it is the right thing to do. I am going to give you some of my thoughts and hopefully some colleagues will add some others. One of the things that I want to point out is that "letting go" is not really a thing. In other words, it's not really something you can reach out and grab. It's more of a process. This is good news because you don't necessarily have to be at the end of the process to end an unhealthy relationship. We just have to accept that there will be feelings that come up even after the relationship is over. For example, someone can end an unhealthy relationship today, but then be reminded of the good times on what would have been their "anniversary." This could make the person very sad. They may even regret ending the relationship for a little while. It would be important, then, for the person to remind themselves why the relationship needed to end and that they are healthier because of it. This is relevant for you. It's hard to walk away from a relationship. We fear all kinds of things, including being single. Sometimes it's helpful to compare what you are getting out of the relationship to what you want from a relationship. It's helpful to be honest about what we have given up for an unhealthy relationship. It's fine to admit uncertainty about ending things.

The organization I work for has told me I cannot go to my 12 step meetings.
This is my recovery, and I don't feel that it is okay for them to ask this. They told me it is policy due to the fact that I may run into a peer there. I am a peer counselor in the small community that I grew up in. I am in recovery myself. I was asked to come work for this organization after I was two years sober I was in treatment in this organization. I work with mental health peers and run life skill groups. I don't work with substance peers.
(Addiction Professional Ethics)

Hello and thank you for your question. I know that workplaces have some flexibility when it comes to requiring certain behaviors from their employees. For example, they may require you to inform them if you get into some kind of legal trouble. But this situation seems completely different. For one thing, 12-step meetings are supposed to be confidential. I am not sure how they would know that you attended unless you or someone else told them. I agree that it seems to cross a line. Usually, each state has an office that manages complaints related to employment, such as the Department of Labor or EEOC. You may want to see which entity is in your state and contact them. It would be worth asking them to see if this is a legal practice. If it is but you still want or need to stay at this job, then you may want to look for alternate sources of support for your sobriety. There are active online support groups that would allow you to do things from the privacy of your home. SMART Recovery is a website that many people like. There are also online groups that specifically discuss the 12 steps. No matter what, I give you a lot of credit for doing your best to keep your sobriety and continuing to see the value in having support.

How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
I've been on 0.5 mg of Xanax twice a day for the past month. It hasn't been helping me at all, but when I take 1 mg during a big anxiety attack, it calms me down. I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.
(Anxiety)

Hello, and thank you for your question. While counselors work closely with medical providers, and sometimes have discussions about medications with people, we rarely make recommendations about how much or what type of medication a person should be taking. This is because prescribing and advising on medication is out of our scope of practice. The only exception would be if a counselor is also a physician, nurse practitioner, physician's assistant, etc. Having said that, I certainly understand that anxiety is a real serious problem that many folks struggle with. If you are currently not in therapy to help you with these panic attacks, you should consider it. Medications can be helpful for anxiety, and medications like Xanax may help for immediate relief, but they do nothing to deal with the root of anxiety and may not help with anxiety long-term. Therapists who have experience in exposure therapies would be good people to start with. Exposure therapy has good outcomes for people with anxiety disorders and panic attacks. If you are interested in speaking with your provider about the Xanax, I think explaining it the way you did on here is just fine. The provider will then decide if they feel comfortable increasing your medication. Please remember that medical providers are not trying to give people a hard time. Medications like Xanax really are highly addictive. The more you take, the more you may feel you need. The more often you may feel you need to use it. Depending on the frequency and amount of use, some people suffer serious withdrawal symptoms when they

My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do.
I am in my early 20s and I still live with my parents because I can't afford to live alone. My mother says that if I live under her roof I have to follow her rules. She is trying to control my life. What should I do?
(Family Conflict Parenting)

Hello. It seems like you and your family might not be effectively communicating and setting expectations. Your personal development depends not only on your ability to learn new things and acquire new skills, but also on your family's recognition and support of your progress. Have you tried discussing your concerns with your family? It's best to have these conversations face to face and during a calm time, not during a conflict or argument. It may also be helpful to write down the ways you think they can support you and how you can support them. You could share this list with them for review, or use it as a guide when discussing expectations. Without clear and expressed expectations, there will continue to be imbalance and increasing frustration.

What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
I have anxieties about everyday stressors, i.e. finances, work, relationships, kids, and maintaining a household.
(Anxiety Stress)

Since it is evident that people react differently to stressors, we understand that the stressors are not causing the anxiety, but rather our thoughts about the stressors. Often, cognitive distortions are the issue. Some common cognitive distortions include catastrophizing (predicting the worst), future telling, black and white thinking (if it's not perfect, it's terrible), mind reading (e.g. "I just know he is angry at me"), and can't stand it-ism (e.g. "I can't stand this situation"). There are more, but the list is long. If some of these resonate with you, I would advise looking up CBT (cognitive behavioral therapy) tips, worksheets, booklets, etc. online, or contacting a local CBT therapist. Another helpful piece of information on anxiety is that it is prone to something called "symptom stress" - being anxious about anxiety. If we could hear this symptom stress, it might sound like, "Oh no, I'm getting nervous about this, I'm getting uptight, I look nervous, what if I have a panic attack," followed by more cognitive distortions such as "I can't stand being anxious" and "this is horrible." The antidote to this is acceptance. Kind of like not stopping the waves but learning to surf instead (Jon Kabat-Zinn). If you happen to feel anxious, say to yourself: "This is just a reaction I'm having that is unpleasant

When should I give up on a relationship?
I've known my boyfriend for several years. We were friends for a long time. In 2013 we started a relationship, and he even asked me to move in with him since I lived out of state. I planned to move in with him in 2014 after I finished school and he found a job. However, during this time we had a few arguments and broke up with each other for a short period of time. We decided later to make it work. Shortly after, I found out that I was pregnant. I wanted to tell him during his next visit. However, he never came to see me and instead asked me for money. After I gave him money, he quit answering my phone calls and texts. Soon after, I experienced a miscarriage. I texted him about what had happened, and he didn't seem to care. I was extremely hurt by this. I still decided to move back as I had originally planned. He helped me with the move and replaced the money I had lent him. During this time, I asked if he wanted to be in this relationship because I needed to know. Although he says he did, I hardly ever see him. He never got a job, which was in the original plan. After that, we both started seeing other people for a short amount of time but once again got back together. Once we got back together, I cut all ties with the former relationship I had been in. I thought he had too. But I found out that he did not attempt to do as I did and was still talking with another woman. In fact, he had even sent inappropriate pictures to her. When I confronted him about this, he wasn't apologetic. He said that he only did it to get even with me and was actually mad at me for looking through his phone. He even closed his car window on my finger and tried to throw me out of his car. I don't know what to do.
(Relationships Domestic Violence)

There are several red flags that you have been presented with. Several breakups, not holding up his end of the bargain regarding work, lack of empathy for your miscarriage, lying about his involvement with another woman, physical violence, which is of most concern. This seems to be a very unhealthy relationship. In my experience, relationships such as these rarely become positive ones. Violence is never okay and regardless of his reasoning, you looking through his phone, it is indefensible. You have to look at these red flags and ask yourself, "Is this really someone I want to marry? Is he an asset to my life?" I think you'll realize he is not. Best of luck to you and please know that you deserve someone who treats you with kindness, dignity, and respect.

My friends don't put effort into our relationship
It's really hard to not have negative feelings about friends who don't put any effort into nourishing our relationship.
(Social Relationships)

Interpersonal relationships, whether positive or negative, involve two or more people who give and receive attention, commitment, time, and communication. What makes friendships special is that they endure through time, especially with those whom we consider our true friends - those who know us well and with whom we share a special connection. We may also experience times of distance from these friends, without fearing the loss of their companionship. 

Consider what you are experiencing in your own life and within your relationships. Speak with your friend about your concerns and let them know that you would like to spend more time together. Plan an activity that both of you enjoy, or try to discover a new hobby together. If your friend is not enthusiastic or engaged, give them some time and focus your energy on spending time with other friends or enjoying activities on your own. After a period of waiting, reach out again to inform your friend about how you are doing and that you still value the friendship. If you continue to feel rejected, take the time to analyze why you value this relationship so much and consider if it's worthwhile to maintain it.

How can my marriage be fixed?
I've only been married three months. Every week, we argue about something, and it seems to be getting worse.
(Marriage)

At the beginning of marriages, we expect to be living on an eternal honeymoon, but the reality can be different. This is a process of adaptation, even if you had known your better half for a long time. During the first months and years of marriage, you go through a process of settling into your new roles and confronting new challenges together, which as you resolve, become new rules and agreements. Yes, you can work through these issues by practicing assertive communication, being clear with each other about what the problem is, how you feel about it, and how you would like to resolve it. Learn to close arguments with resolutions, and remind each other that you care about each other, and that's why you choose to be together. Discuss your roles and expectations. This is normally done over a marriage preparation class. It's never too late to sit down and talk about what you want and look for in a partner and clarify your roles and rules. Find a couples therapist who can mediate communication and help both of you learn assertive communication skills and conflict resolution.

How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
For the past four weeks, I've been having nightmares and hearing voices telling me of horrible things. They're not random voices, but rather, the voices of those I care about.
(Behavioral Change)

Voices and dreams could be suppressed feelings or thoughts that result from negative experiences. Many times when people go through traumatic incidents or changes in their lives without being equipped to manage them, they start having similar symptoms. It is helpful to find a therapist to talk to about those dreams and voices. Once you articulate them, you could analyze the concerns and fears that they reflect and normalize them, which will also be a good time to discuss their source, if any traumatic event has occurred in your life. Also, I recommend journaling your dreams, especially if they keep you awake at night, and meditate afterwards so you can go back to sleep.

How can I control myself and my anger?
I snap easy and push people away. I need help before I push my boyfriend away.
(Anger Management Relationships)

Awareness is the first step. Now that you know that you snap and push people away, you can look into ways to control your anger. If you give yourself the time to analyze why you experience anger, you will discover that there are other feelings underneathâ€”shame, frustration, disappointment, and fear are some of the feelings that we cover with anger when we are not ready to deal with them or don't know how to express them. So next time you feel angry, even if you snap with practice, you will be able to identify them ahead of time, identify why you are angry, and try to express it out loud. A therapist can help you to learn assertive communication skills using examples drawn from your daily experiences.

I'm worried about my new job.
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job. People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?
(Anxiety Career Counseling)

Anxiety often occurs when big or unexpected changes come to our lives, like having new jobs, relocating, or assuming new roles. Notice if your anxiety feels like excitement, concerns, or fear. It seems like you are excited about your new job, but worried because others are telling you that you have anxiety. Let's notice how others' input is affecting your thoughts and maybe causing more anxiety that you may really have. If you are indeed experiencing anxiety, that does not mean that you will have panic attacks. But if you are experiencing panic attacks, or suffer them at some point, you could learn how to reduce them either with therapy or medication. You can learn how to process it depending on what triggers it and channel it in a useful way. For example, you could plan a schedule around your new job and be meticulous about it because you are worried about how your new job may affect your routine, or you could feel overwhelmed with your schedule, focus on the feeling, but not do anything about it. Notice the difference? The key is in recognizing if you are anxious about something that you can change or have control over it, and take action if you do, and recognizing when you cannot control things and be okay with not being in control. I teach clients how to use meditation and cognitive reframing techniques to help calm anxiety symptoms.

My son plays alone at recess.
Is this something I should be worried about? Should I do something about it?
(Parenting)

Sure, here's the updated text:

My son plays alone at recess. Is this something I should be worried about? Should I do something about it? Every mom is the expert on their children's behavior. First of all, I suggest checking with your son, asking him if he is happy while playing alone, or does he complain that no one wants to play with him? Does he play alone in school, but is social in other environments, with family or neighbors? Playing alone is healthy for children, it helps them to be independent and confident, it allows them to explore their environment and use their imagination, among other benefits. On the other hand, it is also important to develop social skills early on and become confident in our skills as we grow. Children go through stages of exploration until they develop a sense of social confidence. Depending on your son's age, he might need some input or advice. Provide the opportunity to interact with other children, without pushing it. Take him to the park to play with a friend or to children's activities in your neighborhood. Later ask him, what did he think of the activity, and if he enjoyed playing there. Children also follow their parent's model, so you can encourage social interaction by greeting others and asking your son to do the same, ask him to receive the guests who come to the house with you and sit to enjoy the conversation. If you notice any shakiness, becoming tearful, anxious or aggressive when approaching social encounters, you

My wife won't do things she used to do
There are intimate things she did early in the relationship, and things she had once agreed to try that she will not do now. I end up thinking about it all day. I feel rejected and think I married the wrong person.
(Intimacy)

After reviewing the text, I have corrected the spellings, removed personal names and contact information, removed any non-English text, and corrected any grammatical errors. Here is the updated text:

"My partner won't do things she used to do. There are intimate activities she did early in the relationship and things she had once agreed to try that she will not do now. I end up thinking about it all day. I feel rejected and think I married the wrong person.

Like we often hear, communication is the key to a good relationship. Intimacy in the marriage is something we take for granted, and we rarely communicate about it. Have you asked if she would like to try new things as well? What if you work on improving your communication with your partner?

One thing to consider is the status of your relationship. Are you in good terms with each other? Are you or your partner going through a stressful situation? Many times when we have problems, we reflect it in multiple areas, including our intimacy or lack of it. Listen to her, ask how you can support her. Find ways to reconnect as a couple, relax, have fun, and do things that you used to enjoy, or discover new interests together.

Then you can focus on having conversations about your intimacy. You could start by letting her know that you are concerned about your romantic life, and ask if you do anything that she likes or dislikes. Remember this is a two-way street; you should be ready to listen

How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?
My mother and I have an okay relationship. I know she loves me unconditionally, and I love her the same. However, more times than not, I'm afraid to tell her anything personal because she either doesn't listen, she turns it around and makes everything about her, or she ignores things even when they are about my mental health.
(Family Conflict)

How can I improve communication with my mother without causing her to become upset? Talking to our loved ones can be complicated, but it is crucial for maintaining a healthy and functional relationship. Sometimes, it may seem challenging to have open conversations with our family members due to the emotions and underlying messages involved. This can be particularly true with our mothers, who often offer advice and feel a strong sense of responsibility towards us. It may seem as though they are making everything about themselves when they express their worries and concerns.

So, what can be done? First, it is important to practice active listening skills to ensure that you are truly receiving and understanding the message, without letting your own emotions or preconceptions influence it. Second, learning and practicing assertive communication skills can be beneficial. This will help you to clearly communicate your message in a respectful manner. It also emphasizes using "I" statements to express your feelings, especially when emotions are involved in the interaction. Third, consider practicing by writing your "I" statements or role-playing with a counselor. The key with communication skills is that they require frequent practice until you have mastered them. If you find it challenging, you can also seek the help of a family therapist to improve these skills, or contact a mediator if more issues arise.

How can I control my anxiety?
I started having anxiety three months ago. I'm new to having anxiety, and it's making me depressed.
(Anxiety Depression)

One of the first steps is to manage anxiety and depression symptoms is to establish a good self-care routine. Start with the most basic things: Eating balanced meals, sleeping for 6-8 hours, and exercising for at least 30 minutes a day. These will help you to regulate the chemical imbalance that affects your mood. Plus, exercising gives you time to vent and be distracted from your thoughts. Once basic self-care is established, I suggest that it's a good time to start exploring the source of these feelings and address them through therapy. If you have difficulty initiating self-care routine, talk to your therapist about what motivates you and pushes you to do things. You might find the key during the process. You could also discuss medication options if it's too challenging to begin basic self-care with your physician or a psychiatrist.

Does my daughter have a mental disability?
My daughter is in later elementary school. She can't color in the lines. Her words jumble together when she writes unless there are big spaces or she skips lines.
(Parenting)

Depending on your daughter's age, this could be a learning disability. I suggest contacting the school counselor and asking for an evaluation, once she is evaluated and depending on the diagnosis, she could be provided with treatment recommendations like occupational therapy, reading glasses, or assistance in class. These and more accommodations are enforced under the 504 act. Consider if the observations that you have made are affecting her performance in school only, or also in other settings. Observe her behavior and/or her emotions and see if they change as well. Discuss these with your daughter's counselor as well.

Why can't I get an erection with my girlfriend?
I love my girlfriend so much. I get an erection even just thinking about her or seeing her. But the two times we tried to have sex I couldn't get an erection. We've only had sex once and it was a long time ago. Why this is happening and what can I do about it?
(Human Sexuality Intimacy)

This is a topic that I have had to address frequently since working with couples is one of the main focuses of my practice. The answer can depend on several reasons, all of which tend to be explored during our sessions. If you or your counselor uses an integral approach, ensuring to check the four irreducible perspectives - subjective, intersubjective, objective, and interobjective (also known as the four quadrants) - in determining where the challenges are, it then becomes possible to identify what might be contributing to or causing the challenge, as well as offering ways to address the situation.

In this case, from a behavioral and physical perspective, we would want to make sure there are no physical limitations or ailments, meaning that you would need to visit your doctor and have the basics checked, such as blood pressure. We would also look at particular behaviors to see if you are doing something that is affecting performance, such as excessive masturbation or being influenced by pornography.

Next, we would look at the thoughts, cognitions, identity, and feelings, to see what is going on both during sexual activities and at other times. If you are worried about your job, your family, or under immense pressure to perform at work or during intimate moments, this can contribute to your situation. 

We would then turn to the cultural rules and tools to see how you have learned to interpret challenges that come up during sex and look for ways to shift, update, and reshape the way you view sex and its challenges. It

How do I fall back in love with my wife?
My wife works late most days, so I'm lonely. I love my wife with all my heart, however I don't feel the intimacy we used to have. We don't have sex anymore, which bothers me tremendously. I have become close friends with a coworker, which I know is not helping. Nothing will happen with that, but there's the thought.
(Marriage Intimacy)

Certainly! Here's the updated text data:

First things first. Friendships that develop in times of struggle may be a great emotional support, but also become confusing due to sexual attraction. Entertaining a tough is only going to make it a stronger target. Careful with that friendship. You do not want to fill your marriage's void with another person. Even when you are in a friend zone and not having intimacy with this person, you may be developing a special bond, sharing interests and activities that may lead to a deeper connection. Ask yourself how you would feel if your partner was having a friendship like that. Then try to refocus on your marriage. I suggest being transparent and talking to your partner about your feelings and concerns. Ask them what you could do to reconnect, make some suggestions, and dedicate time to practice them. Make time in both of your schedules, make an effort to have meals together, or to communicate during the day. Remember that a marriage is like a very good friendship with benefits, but sometimes the responsibility kills the fun.

What can I do when I feel like my life is out of control?
I was in a car accident and totaled my car. I gave up my job of nine years to pursue school fulltime to better myself. I failed a class, and my boyfriend that I live with thinks I'm stupid and wants to break up with me. I have nowhere to go, and I feel like I'm losing everything.
(Stress Anxiety)

When we feel overwhelmed by life situations, it is important to understand where the feeling is coming from. Once we understand the source, it is important to normalize the situations that got us there and find balance in our lives. First, car accidents are common, and since they are accidents they are not a reflection of us. When we have an accident we feel anxious, worried, and may have some trauma after the accidents. If you have been experiencing anxiety since the car accident, talk to your doctor or therapist about it. Basically, your response is the fight, flight or freeze reaction which is hard wired into the human nervous system, specifically, the autonomic nervous system called the autonomic response. This system is responsible for regulating the heart, digestion, respiratory rate as well as other aspects which match the symptoms you describe. It is largely an unconscious function, but with training it can be managed such as a public speaking course in which you prepare and even have some exposure to smaller experiences to help you prepare and cope for larger presentations. One of the greatest applications of addressing this response is the program which exposes the astronauts to situations they will encounter while in space which will trigger the response so that when it does happen not if but when that they are able to move through the challenge with success. Hi there, relationships with therapists have some things in common with other relationships; they work best if there is dialogue about what your hopes, thoughts, emotions, and needs are. Are you letting your therapist know what your goals are? It's okay to say "I'd really like us to focus on this piece" or "I'm looking for specific direction on how to manage this part." Your therapist is wise if they ask questions that determine what your needs are, but they can't read your mind.

Not every therapist will be a good fit for you. We have different styles; some are more passive and focus on listening. This might be the type of therapist you have. For some people, this is what they want, but maybe it's not for you. Maybe you want someone who digs at you more, asks more questions, gives you strategies, and lets you know what they think... someone more active. If this is the case, it doesn't mean they are a bad therapist... it's just not what you're looking for.

Sometimes people think they can't end sessions with their therapist; they might be worried about hurt feelings. But, in the end, you don't owe your therapist anything if you feel it's not working or it's not a good match. Just move on and try someone new. Maybe ask them questions first about their style, even.

Best of luck!

My daughter calls me crazy, and I'm not sure how to handle that.
I am divorced and happily remarried. Our blended family of children are in their 20s. My youngest, age 20, continues to call me crazy and favors her dad. He was abusive to me, and I left with injuries. He never wanted kids, and I did. He paid child support only through forced wage earners. Now my daughters favor him after all the sacrifices I made for them the past 15 years as a single mom. I don't deny them a relationship with their dad, but to be called crazy and then watch them hang out with him hurts me to the very core. I'm not sure how to handle this.
(Parenting Relationship Dissolution  Family Conflict)

Hi, Your situation sounds like a case of parental alienation. Your ex-partner unfortunately has the power to say things to your children that poison their relationship with you. It's a form of abuse and child abuse. He's likely doing this to hurt you and have power over you, and he's not considering how it's affecting the kids. I've seen this happen in many families - parents who once had a strong loving relationship with their children suddenly feel abandoned in favor of the other parent. In some cases, children actually stop having contact with one parent, who is left bewildered and powerless. It's your ex's job to support your relationship with your kids, not try to destroy it.

While you can't change his behaviors, and I think you know that, there are things you can do for yourself and your kids. For your children, you can refuse to enter into the war he's setting up. He's trying to provoke you into acting "crazy", but you don't have to fall for this. If you run around screaming "he's lying", it only makes you look more 'crazy'. Try to stay calm, and don't put their dad down to them, no matter how tempting it is. One day, they may be ready to hear the truth of your relationship with their father, but wait until they ask. Trust that they have their own experience of their dad, and trust that he doesn't have the power to destroy their love for you. Children, in the long term, lose respect for parents who denigrate the other parent. They see who their dad is already, I'd bet, but they don't know how to cope with that. If he's the only one fighting a war, you're helping them feel less trapped in a parental conflict. Don't engage on his level.

Don't blame your children completely. Although I have to say that for them to call you names like crazy is not acceptable and you don't need to tolerate that disrespect, try to deal with this behavior without bringing their dad into it. They are acting out their father's agenda, likely because they instinctively see his weakness. Children often support the weaker parent, rather than abandon them. You get the worst because they trust your love. But you can still have boundaries. Letting them abuse you isn't the answer, but have compassion for their position. This picture isn't their fault, but as adults, they can be held accountable for their choices. Reassure yourself that you are the mom you know you are. You don't need them to gush all over you in order to know that you made sacrifices. Hold onto the likelihood that someday, they will come back and be grateful. It may take a while, you can't rush it, but they will see you for who you are. Your power is in giving them a consistently calm, generous, connected, supportive mom who refuses to play games or be walked on.

I'd recommend trying to connect with other parents who experience this phenomenon, or a therapist who can reinforce these goals and help keep you grounded. Good luck.

Why do I still feel a connection with my exboyfriend that hurt me very badly?
My exboyfriend boyfriend and I lived together. He had a two year affair with a girl and had three pregnancies with her. One was an abortion, another was a miscarriage, and then she had the third baby. They are not together, but he continues to contact me and wants me back. He has nothing to offer me.
(Relationships Relationship Dissolution  Intimacy)

Hi there,

This is a common question that many people struggle with: why can't they forget about or stop connecting with someone who they know isn't good for them?

In your case, part of the problem is that this person keeps trying to get back in touch with you. For some individuals, it's a game to see how much power they have over you, or it's their need to control you. If you don't want any contact from this person, it's crucial to clearly communicate your boundaries by saying "Don't contact me again," and then ignore all of their messages. Any interaction or response from you will only encourage their behavior. Remind yourself why you don't want to be with them. I hear you doing that already when you say "he has nothing to offer me." That's great self-talk.

But let's discuss why it's difficult to let go of people like this. Sometimes, it's because we still hope they will change. We may remember who they used to be or how they used to treat us, and we think it can go back to how it felt in those "good old days." However, during the initial years of intimacy, people tend to show more of who they really are, not less. So, what they're eventually showing you is their true selves and what they're capable of. People can change and grow, but it won't happen at your pace. Accept them for who they are and stop expecting them to change.

Another reason we can't let go is because we picture our ex with someone new in the future, wondering if they will be a better person for their next partner. This thought is normal, but not healthy. It's as though we want them to stay, apologize, heal our wounds, and make up for past mistakes. You deserve healing, you deserve better than what you got, and you deserve apologies. However, expecting all of this from the person who hurt you and hasn't shown compassion yet is probably unwise.

I believe that underlying some of the scenarios mentioned above is the deep belief that we are somehow responsible for the pain our exes caused. If you blame yourself in any way for someone's mistreatment of you, you will keep trying to change yourself so that they can treat you better. Let me remind you that their actions are about them, not you, and the only solution is to challenge and minimize thoughts of them and create distanceâ€”both physically and emotionally. These steps, along with time, will help the events of the past fade in significance.

How do I open up to someone?
Ever since my exboyfriend and I broke up, I can't seem to get close to anyone else. I know I'm completely over him, but I just can't break down my walls and let someone new into my life.
(Relationships Social Relationships Intimacy)

Hi [Name], You're scared, right? That makes sense. Each time we have a breakup, we are a bit more in touch with how much is at stake in this whole love and relationship business. We are falling in love and letting someone close to our hearts, and there's vulnerability in that we can get hurt. Who you partner with long-term is a big decision and it determines 90% of our happiness in life. The good news is that when we're just starting to get to know someone, we can take it slow. I think maybe you are slowing yourself down instinctively here, and that's okay. We are naturally people of attachment and it won't likely last if you are normally an open and accessible person who doesn't put up walls. So part of what I want to say here is don't pressure yourself too much. Take the time to heal naturally and listen to your instinct that is telling you to take things slow. As well, there are a few things you can do to make sure that the walls do eventually come down, or will come down for the right person. First, think about the lessons you learned from this past relationship. What do you feel proud of? What do you need in a partner? What mistakes did you make? Use this experience to grow in your awareness of how you work in a relationship and what you need from a partner. Look at your thoughts. Are you having generalized negative thoughts like "No one will ever love me again?" or "I'm going to get hurt again" or "I can't trust myself"? If so, write down what these thoughts are, and then ask yourself what evidence supports these thoughts. Fear tries to convince us that there is either something wrong with us or that something bad will happen, but it does so with little or no evidence of this ever happening. It sells us a line based on no concrete evidence. Then ask yourself what evidence supports the opposite thought. What is the evidence that I am lovable... that there are safe, good people out there... that I can trust myself? Eliminate the negative thoughts and add the positive ones. It's simple but very powerful. Lastly, take concrete and careful steps to act as though there are no walls. What is the evidence of the walls? Can you take purposeful baby steps in the direction of lowering those walls? When we act as though something is true, we start to feel it and believe it more. I hope you will find yourself back on track eventually, with time.

How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
My toddler defies everything I say and doesn't see me as authoritative, so she says no about everything. I'd like to hear some ways I can work on not needing to feel so much in control all the time.
(Anxiety Parenting)

Hi, Biddeford. This is a super goal. Feeling powerless is something parents are wise to get used to. There's a creature in the home whose job is to find and use their power in the family and in the world. Of course, your toddler defies you, and that's healthy. I worry more about the overly compliant ones. She is wanting to know what the rules are, and all you have to do is show her clearly where the lines are. I'll give you some tips.

First, remind yourself that it's her job to learn what the rules are and where her power is. Don't be surprised when she wants it her way. If we go through our days being ready and prepared for these beautiful creatures to have minds of their own, we're less caught off guard when it happens.

Avoid situations that invite power struggles. Any time you tell your daughter "do this now," you set up a power struggle. The good thing is that she's young enough you can pick her up. Now is the time to teach her that mom's or dad's word means something. So, if you say "let's get you dressed," then be prepared to pick her up right away and show her that when you say something will happen, you can make it happen. And I'm talking about gently picking her up hereâ€¦ not roughly. Pick your battles; only give instructions when you have the power to make it happen.

Give her choices, so she can see her power. Instead of opening her drawer and asking what she wants to wear, give her two choices. Here's an example: she's on the iPad, and you say iPad time is over. She says "no". You can say "iPad time is over. If you put it down, you can play later. If I have to take it away, you don't play it later." The choice is hers. Then follow through.

"When...then" statements are really helpful. Your child asks for something. Instead of saying no, try "as soon as the toys are picked up, we can have a snack". You're simply a pleasant parent who wants the same thing they do... but they have to earn it.

Staying calm yourself is the key because then at least you will feel in control of yourself, which is the ultimate goal. Use self-talk to calm yourself. Remind yourself her behavior is normal and healthy. Breathe through a moment in which you would have reacted, and it will be over by the time the breath is done. You can give yourself time to think before you make parenting decisions. Time is a useful tool not enough parents use. Good luck.

I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup.
A girl and I were madly in love. We dated for over a year and were even talking about marriage and future plans together. She moved away for school, and we attempted a long distance relationship. We eventually broke up. It's been a year now, and I still haven't lost my feelings for her. I still love her the same way I did. I've suffered from depression ever since the breakup and have been unable to connect with anyone else. It's damaging me and my life.
(Relationship Dissolution  Depression Social Relationships)

Hi, I'm sorry that you've lost the love you had. The fact that you were planning on getting married and building a future together indicates that you held a special place in each other's hearts. However, things have changed now and you're no longer together. Accepting this reality might be challenging for you, but it's crucial for your well-being. You've been grieving for a longer time than the duration of your relationship. It's important to understand that you're still stuck in your feelings for her instead of moving forward. Unrequited love can lead to long-lasting heartache. Let's consider some potential obstacles that are preventing you from moving on.

Perhaps there are unresolved issues for you. Maybe you were hurt and never had the opportunity to express your feelings, or maybe you hurt her and didn't have a chance to make amends. It's possible that there's a burning question you need to ask or something else you want to say. You might even want to let her know that you still love her and see if she feels the same way. In such a case, you have two choices. You can reach out and communicate what's on your mind, or you can stop dwelling on these thoughts and let them go. If you decide to reach out, there's no guarantee that the outcome will be positive or that she will even respond. You could consider writing a letter to her but not sending it, or you can choose to send it. It might be worth taking the risk. The following paragraph will help you make a decision.

Do you know how she feels about you? How did the relationship end? Did she end it? Was the distance the reason behind the breakup, or were there other underlying differences that caused the relationship to fail? Sometimes, when people are deeply in love, they fail to realize that the other person no longer shares the same feelings. Consider the information you have about what she wants in life. Can you respect and support her needs? If she has asked for distance, it would be wise for you to honor her request.

A key aspect of moving forward is examining your thoughts and identifying where you're getting stuck. Write down your thoughts and determine what negative consequences you associate with letting go. For example, "If I let go, something bad might happen" or "Moving forward would mean...". Continue exploring these thoughts and pinpoint the worst possible outcome. This kind of introspection can help you identify the areas where you're feeling stuck.

It's possible that you've interpreted the end of this relationship as a reflection of yourself or your future in a negative light. For instance, you may think, "If this person doesn't love me, then I must be unlovable" or "No one will ever love me as much as she did". Holding onto your feelings for her is your way of rejecting these negative beliefs about yourself or your future. Can you find a different way to challenge and reject these beliefs? Try repeating the following affirmations to yourself:

- I know that she loved me. There is evidence of her love.
- I was a good partner. There is evidence of my positive qualities.
- Falling in love and moving on are normal parts of life. I have the strength to learn and grow from this experience.
- Many people appreciate and value me; that's how I know I am worthy of love.
- It's natural to feel sadness. I'm allowed to grieve the loss of love.
- I want to look ahead and not dwell on the past.

Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom.
We are the legal guardianship of our grandson. He has been acting out, and he wants to talk to his mom that has not talked to him since before last year. How are we to handle this?
(Parenting)

Hi, This depends a lot on their age and the situation. The younger the child is, in general, the more I would see this as their decision, not theirs. A child of any age should be listened to carefully about these matters but just because a child has unresolved issues about a parent doesn't necessarily mean that having contact is a good solution. Some questions... Was the parent harmful to the child? Is the parent likely to be harmful to the child? How likely is it to be a positive experience? Do you have any contact with the parent? You may want to speak with the parent first to determine whether they are in a stable enough place to allow this to happen. I would start by asking the child more about what is on their mind. What do they want to get out of a visit with the parent? Is it to see them and know the parent is okay, to get an apology, to apologize for a perceived hurt, to have regular contact, to find out if they are loved...? What do they hope mom or dad might do or say in the visit? There are many possible goals this child might have in mind. This will give you a sense of what's missing for the child, what need are they trying to fill. Once you know the need, try to determine the likelihood of that need being met successfully through contact. Once you determine the risk of the child's need not being met, then you decide whether it makes sense. The older the child, the more able they are to determine this with you or for themselves. There are other options than face-to-face. They can write to their mom or dad, text or email. It's likely that the child is looking for a sense that they are loved, wanted, worth some effort. When a child is separated from a parent, they tend to blame themselves. Whether they see the parent or not, they will need extra love, attention, and support than a child who has two loving, present parents. I wish them the best and I'm grateful for the love and support you continue to give your grandchild. You're very special.

Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
Sometimes I can't stop thinking about life after death. I was raised in a religion that teaches that we will live on forever either in hell or in heaven. When I think of living forever even if it is in heaven which should be good, I feel overwhelmed. I don't like the thought of living forever and ever and ever. Sometimes I just can't get the thought out of my mind and the thoughts lead to panic and anxiety. Am I crazy? I don't think these thoughts are normal.
(Anxiety Spirituality)

Hi there, what you're experiencing is indeed anxiety. It's very common, and through research, we know a lot about how to reduce anxiety. I'll get you started, and it's a great idea to connect with a therapist who can build on these ideas and get to know you well.

It's natural to have random thoughts that unsettle us. Our brains are complex, wonderful things. Fearful and anxious thoughts are a part of this picture â€“ their purpose is to prepare us for the future and to help us make sense of the past and learn from it. But what happens sometimes is that our alarm systems get out of whack and get set off too easily. We often spend too much time worrying about things that happened or might happen. When these thoughts take away from our enjoyment of life, it becomes a problem. 

So, while fear and anxiety try to protect us, they also seek power and will take any power they can get. In general, fear and anxiety try to tell us one or both of two things: that something is wrong with us, or that something bad will happen because there's something wrong with us. They will use anything they can as evidence to convince you. For example, "That person looked at you funny. You're strange looking." Well, there are dozens of possible explanations for the look on that person's face, and it's unlikely it had anything to do with you.

For you personally, your thoughts are about the afterlife and living forever. What does fear tell you will be uncomfortable about living forever? What would the worst part be? A therapist would help you dig deep to find the core of what you fear. It might be that you have no control over who you are or where you go. It might be that you fear going to hell because you're "bad". Search for that deepest fear.

I invite you then to picture that thought as a glass of water on a shelf. It's a heavy glass, and if you held it in your hands for a while and stared at it, it would get in the way â€“ you'd be uncomfortable and unable to focus on your life. That's what's happening now. I suggest that the problem is not so much the thought you're having. We all have random silly thoughts that usually aren't true. The problem is how long you're holding it in your hand. You could have that thought, pick up that glass a hundred times a day, and as long as you put it right back on the shelf, it's not a problem. The trick is to get it back on that shelf.

Right now, you're using distraction to do this. You're trying to focus on other things around you, but I think the glass is still in your hand. It's not enough â€“ you're looking for more tools to get that glass back on the shelf. And the key is in your thoughts. Once you find out what fear is trying to tell you, then you can "talk back to" fear. So, as an example, if fear is saying to you, "You have no control over anything," then you can work to accept the pieces you don't have control over, learn to tolerate that feeling, and claim back the pieces you can control. You can control the extent to which you let fear take you over.

With a therapist, you can learn to "refute" fear's ideas. You can learn to look for concrete evidence of fear's lies and gain back control over your thoughts. I wish you the best.

How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
Whenever I run into a situation that makes me upset or angry, I tend to start cursing and badly offending the person I am confronting. I say mean things to let my anger out. Whenever people tell me stuff about my relationship like starting rumors or saying negative things about me or my relationship I lash out not just them but at my boyfriend. I feel like I keep causing drama due to my personality. I want to be a better person and learn to let things not get to me and be happy and graceful. I hurt the ones I love with my words. I want to be better for myself and them.
(Anger Management Relationships Social Relationships)

Hi there, I'm happy to hear that you want to tackle this problem. Relationships don't tend to last when we treat people poorly. It is very possible for you to learn different ways of relating with some strong effort. I would highly suggest working with a therapist, and I will give you a few things to think about in the meantime.

Sometimes anger is there because we feel something is unjust or unfair, but many times, anger is a "secondary emotion," and it's simply there to protect us from other, more vulnerable emotions that we would rather not feel and will do anything to avoid. Discovering what vulnerable emotions you are protecting yourself from is important. Perhaps you feel powerless, unloved, or unimportant. It may take some time before you recognize this emotion.

Once you do, you can ask yourself about the other times in your life when you have felt that emotion. Where did it originate? At what age did you feel "too much" of that feeling...so much so that you can't stand it even in tiny amounts?

You will learn in therapy to identify the thoughts you have that are connected to that feeling. They are typically incorrect thoughts, like "No one loves me" or "People will always hurt me." Fear tends to generalize and predict bad things that aren't likely.

Your habit is so strong that you likely have a poor sense of self-worth and you don't believe people will love you...so you hurt them to keep them at a distance. This happens at a subconscious level. Do you see how that would help you keep people off balance or afraid or at a distance if you didn't believe in your worth? So, it's really backwards because you think you're getting mad at people who "piss you off," but you're really just not wanting to face how mad you are at yourself.

In addition to this work, you can start to intentionally treat people more kindly. Find out what respect is, make amends, and resolve to spread peace. It might sound too simple, but if you act as though you're a person of peace, you will start to feel more peaceful.

But I hope you do contact a therapist. It will take time and support to reach your goal.

How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
I have been in a relationship with my boyfriend for about six years now. In the past, our relationship was difficult and frustrating. We argued a lot, and due to that, there was a lot of tension between us. We stayed together because we love each other and wanted to make it work. I used to party a lot, and several times I got into situations where I would end up kissing someone else. These situations were never more than just kissing. I have come clean about these situations with my boyfriend, and he decided to forgive and move forward with me. I love him so much and want to work things out too, but I'm having a difficult time understanding how he can forgive me. I can't seem to forgive myself. I'm overwhelmed with feelings of guilt and unworthiness.
(Relationships Selfesteem)

Hi, This is an interesting twist because it's more common for the person in your position to want to move forward, and for the person who was wronged to struggle with forgiveness. You are lucky to have a loving, compassionate partner, and your partner is lucky to have a partner who takes full responsibility for their actions.

My hunch is that you learned some things about yourself when you were younger that are playing a role here. Your sense of worthlessness seems out of proportion to the mistakes you made. You don't have to be perfect in order to deserve the love of a good person. You only have to have the maturity to recognize when you've hurt someone and work hard to make it better. Who in your life overreacted to small mistakes you made? Were you shamed as a child? Did you learn that you deserved to be punished? Did something bad happen that you thought was your fault? Is there a mistake you made long ago that you need forgiveness for? There is a younger person inside you waiting to be forgiven for something they weren't entirely responsible for. The bar is too high for you. If I was your therapist, I would work with you to find the source of the shame, and address that wound.

If you want to move forward and be with your partner, your job will be to forgive yourself. Forgiving doesn't mean "it was okay", forgiving simply means that it happened, that you can't erase it, and that you don't want to carry it around or punish yourself for it anymore.

You have done many things here that you can feel proud of. You've 'come clean', you've been honest, you've taken responsibility for your actions, you've not tried to minimize what you did, and you've chosen to be more loyal and aware of how you impact your partner. These are all things you can use to build your sense of worth. You are acting very honorably. It's time to put your past mistakes away on the shelf knowing that you've learned from them and are a better person now. It's not our mistakes, not our worst moments that define us, it's how we handle them afterwards.

I wish you growth and happiness.

Once you see where your personal barriers are, and you start to refute those thoughts in your mind, you can begin to build new ideas about yourself and other people that are based on compassion instead of fear. I don't know what to do about my son's lying.
My son stole my debit card and lied about it. It's not the first time he has lied. I don't know what to do anymore. I don't know if I should punish him or make him do something. I've tried talking to him and asking if anything was wrong. I have grounded him, but nothing works. What should I do?
(Parenting)

Hi, you sound like a sensitive parent. I like that you talked to your child to see if anything is wrong. There is some important information missing here. I don't know your child's age, whether they spent any money, whether they put the card back, or how many times they have stolen. My answer might be different depending on those details, but I'll give you my thoughts.

I believe it is every child's job to figure out the rules and find their power in the world. Testing limits is a common behavior for many children. They often ask themselves, "What can I get away with?" in order to find the answer. If a child knows the rules, they are less likely to test the limits because they already know what they are. Therefore, part of testing limits includes experimenting with stealing and lying. Not all children steal, but I would say that almost every child lies at some point. It is a normal behavior, and most of the time it involves small things that don't matter and we may never find out about.

Stealing a debit card is a more serious offense, and it's not surprising that your child lied about it. If you are absolutely sure that they took it, it's okay to tell them that you believe they did this and also lied about it. It's appropriate to give a consequence for this type of behavior, so that the child understands it is not acceptable. The consequence should be as natural and logical as possible. Stealing the debit card was harmful to you, so perhaps having them do extra chores would be a good idea.

It's interesting how as parents, we try to teach our children that lying is bad, but they know that they will face consequences if they tell the truth. There are natural deterrents to being honest because we don't want people to know about our mistakes. It's a dilemma. If you really want to focus on the lying part, you can tell your child that you won't give them a consequence for lying if they decide to come clean with the truth within one day. That gives them an incentive to come to you with the truth. Sometimes, giving kids a chance to be honest and rewarding them for telling the truth works.

You can set your child up for success by teaching them the importance of honesty. For example, you can put a cookie on the counter and tell your child to take the cookie at some point during the day. Later, ask them if they took the cookie. This makes honesty fun and engaging. Kids love games.

In essence, rewarding positive behavior can be just as powerful as punishing negative behavior. If this is your son's first serious offense, don't make a big deal out of it. Give him a consequence and see if he learns from it. However, if this behavior becomes a pattern, it may be helpful to seek the input of a therapist.

Hi,

First, she hasn't asked yet, and you don't know that she will. Right now, you can pleasantly ignore her hints. They're not hurting you and if you ignore them, they're more likely to go away. You can address and reduce your own anxiety about the possibility of her asking by reassuring yourself that you have the right as parents to make this decision, and that if she's offended, that doesn't mean that you're being mean, it means that she has unrealistic expectations. So, the first goal is to put it out of your mind as a worry. You might never have to face that moment. But, I understand that you want to be prepared.

As her son, perhaps your husband is the best one to answer the question, should it ever come. Is he willing to do this? But if you are comfortable, and if you're the one she asks, you can confidently give her a simple, honest response about why it won't happen. And I would suggest presenting a firmly closed door, rather than saying "but maybe later". No need to apologize or hum and haw..."We love that you want to be around [Child's Name], and we definitely want you in [Child's Name]'s life. Try to leave out the "but" here. You're not in a healthy place, and we're not comfortable with you caring for [Child's Name] on your own."

If she pushes the issue, this is evidence of her denial or inappropriate boundaries. Learning not to take responsibility for her emotions is part of having an ill person in your life. I wish you the best.

When someone tells you, "You're so ungrateful," what they actually mean is, "I need you to succeed and be happy so that I can consider myself a good parent." Similarly, when they say, "You're too young to be depressed," what they're actually saying is, "I don't want to confront your mental health issues at the moment. I'll ignore it, so I won't have to face my fear and embarrassment." Hi, I understand that you are working on overcoming overreactions and improving trust in your relationship with your boyfriend. It's important to recognize that some individuals may engage in infidelity while others do not. However, it's crucial to give our partners the benefit of the doubt unless they display signs of untrustworthiness. There are two aspects to consider in addressing this issue. Firstly, if you want to develop a more trusting mindset, you should examine your thoughts and behaviors.

It seems that your thoughts are trapped in negative patterns, similar to tires stuck in deep ruts on a road. These thoughts are merely habits and do not necessarily reflect reality. Fear might be influencing your thinking, whispering phrases like "everyone cheats" or "you're not enough for him". Once you identify the message that fear is trying to convey, visualize those words in red when they arise. Then, ask yourself about the proof supporting those thoughts. You will likely find little or no evidence to support them. In contrast, remind yourself that there are many good men, that you deserve love and loyalty, and that there are no signs of infidelity. By challenging and refuting fear-based thoughts, you can begin to break free from their hold. Practice these thoughts regularly to reinforce positive thinking.

The second aspect involves your behaviors. Act as if you trust your boyfriend. Resist the urge to constantly check or question him. The less you engage in these behaviors, the less obsessive and untrusting you will feel. It may feel unnatural at first, but acting "as if" something is true can actually help foster genuine belief. Remember that changing our thoughts can ultimately transform our emotions.

To initiate this process, you might consider seeking the assistance of a therapist who specializes in cognitive behavioral therapy. They can provide support and guidance in exploring the underlying reasons behind your current struggles and help you develop strategies to overcome them. I wish you the best of luck in this journey.

Hi, I felt a bit sad when I read this. This is a new term for me... "semirelationship". What does it mean? I know that today's culture for young people is more of a "hookup" culture than a dating one. Maybe that means that you develop connections to people but you keep yourself from hoping for a full relationship because no one is doing that anymore. That makes me feel sad. I hear a lot of young women say that they struggle with hookups because they can't let themselves hope for a phone call after a hookup. Research tells us that, after a hookup, college-age women tend to feel used and unworthy, and men tend to feel guilty. I think this scenario works better for men than women, but many of both genders are left unsatisfied in the end. This is only one possible explanation for your anxiety... that your gut knows that it wants to feel fully coupled with someone but you struggle with whether it's okay to want or expect that. Maybe take a moment and listen to anxiety. Anxiety tends to try to convince us that something's wrong with us or something bad's going to happen. Anxiety sometimes prefers to stay vague; it's more difficult to refute it then, but you can try to clarify its whisperings by asking yourself these questions: What am I afraid of? What is the worst thing that might happen here? Then what might happen, and what would be the worst part of that? Keep going until you find the very worst thing that might happen. Might someone not want you? Might you feel rejected? Or feel not good enough? You might get hurt? Then when you find that core fear, you can look at your life and I bet you'd find a place where that idea or fear originated. A big moment or many smaller ones when you actually DID feel or get rejected or abandoned or hurt. In the end, it's a feeling you're trying to avoid, not life or relationship, and anxiety is trying to help you avoid it by making you overcautious. But this doesn't work for you. Good With the help of a qualified therapist, you can learn to talk back to anxiety and move forward in life and love with calm confidence.

Although I suggest you leave the parenting to him, what you can do is tell him what you see, offer suggestions if he's open to it, and talk about the ways in which the situation affects you. I asked if he had been drinking, but he snapped and said no. I went into our room to sleep, leaving him on the couch. I'm not sure if I'm overreacting or not. I just feel like I'm so honest with him about everything, and I expect the same honesty. He is a good husband in every other regard.
(Addiction Marriage Intimacy)

Hi, So your spouse is giving you conflicting messages. They claim to be willing to reduce their alcohol consumption, but they continue to drink secretly. Their behavior is passive-aggressive and immature, which puts you in the position of being a disapproving parent. It seems like you're dealing with an unruly teenager rather than a partner.

Your spouse's dishonesty is sending a message. Perhaps it's "I have the right to make my own decisions, and you can't control me." Beneath that, maybe it's "I want to quit, but I feel ashamed that I can't, and I don't want you to witness my failures." Ultimately, as adults, we have the autonomy to choose what we consume. If you try to manage their drinking by keeping track of the number of beers they have, you'll likely encounter some negative consequences, resistance, or backlash.

How does their drinking affect you? Your voice holds power in this area. It's better to focus on that rather than counting beers or setting them up to lie when they're unconscious. Asking if they've been drinking when they've passed out is confusing. You've mentioned that they snore, which I suppose is a valid complaint. If they're passing out regularly, that's a genuine concern. Do they drive or behave aggressively when they drink? Do they disconnect from the relationship and avoid you? These are all valid concerns, and it's best to discuss them instead of fixating on beer count.

I suspect that your spouse has limited coping mechanisms for stress, so they turn to alcohol to numb themselves and evade dealing with your relationship. However, this only exacerbates the situation; the more they distance themselves from you, the more you pursue them with your questions.

A helpful conversation to have is one that goes like this: "I've tried supporting you in drinking less, and it hasn't been effective. What are your goals when it comes to alcohol, and how can I better support you?" It would be great to reach a point where you're not micromanaging their drinking but instead focusing on the aspects that directly impact you. What specific supportive strategies can you both agree on? Can you remove alcohol from the house? Is your spouse open to seeking treatment?

Clearly communicate your expectations. Say, "I won't keep tabs on your beer consumption, but I can't tolerate dishonesty." Ultimately, you have to determine what's truly important to you. Is it solely the quantity of beer, or is it something deeper? What changes do you need to see in order to want to stay in the marriage? And what does your spouse require? Do they express their own boundaries effectively? They may struggle to articulate their needs.

The issue of drinking is just one aspect of the complex dynamics within your marriage. It would be beneficial to involve a qualified therapist who can help unravel and understand these complexities, and guide you both in developing healthier ways of relating to each other.

Work on that file...strengthen it. Having a strong "they do care about me and wouldn't hurt me again" file will help you.

Other things that they can do to help you strengthen that file, because after all, their behaviors caused this problem, are to answer all your questions, not brush you off if you're feeling insecure, treat you as though you're a priority, avoid questionable contact with others, have open communication, and give you passwords to devices so there is transparency. They can help you understand where those behaviors came from...why they cheated in the first place, although people aren't always good with those 'why' questions.

You can focus on telling yourself that people change, that they deserve a chance to show you they can be loyal, or at least you've decided to give them that chance, and that you want to be a trusting person. If you act like a trusting person, you will likely feel more like one. Don't go snooping, don't interrogate them. It's normal to feel scared, so try to communicate your fears with them. Let them know what happens that leads to you feeling scared.

This is a start for you. A good therapist can also be helpful too.

However, there are complications, and one of the drawbacks is that you can develop a strong emotional connection and genuine care for someone before ever meeting them in person. Subsequently, when you do meet in person and that magnetic physical attraction is absent, you find yourself in a challenging situation because you have already established a connection based on other aspects. It can be quite awkward then to express, "Now that I have met you, it doesn't feel the way I anticipated." Just because you do not find yourself attracted to him does not make you a bad person, nor does it imply that he is unattractive. Hi, my heart goes out to you. Sometimes when working with clients experiencing depression or anxiety, I ask them about their darkest thoughts. "What are the worst thoughts that go through your mind?" They often struggle, maybe out of shame or fear of being judged. However, knowing their worst thoughts can help me provide better support because we have a starting point. You feel hopeless and worthless, and your thoughts reinforce these intense emotions.

Although I don't know you personally, I firmly believe that there is someone in your life who would hear your thoughts and say, "That's not true. I know your worth." I believe that there are people who can see your true value, even in the small things. Can you imagine hearing those voices?

Since you mentioned God, let's bring God into the conversation. What might God say to you? What evidence might God, who sees all, have of your worth? Perhaps God could give you a hint about your purpose.

You suffer from severe anxiety, and agoraphobia works in tandem with fear. Fear tells you that people will reject you or that something equally terrible will happen, and then agoraphobia comes in and traps you, using the fact that it seems like no one is reaching out to you as evidence that you have no worth. Can you see their plan? They want to make you scared, keep you isolated, and convince you that it's hopeless. However, they are both lying to you. They only want power over you.

You forget your worth. You forget that we all have worth. No one is a waste. I believe that all of God's creatures have worth, and we are here to use our gifts to make the world a better place and to remind one another of our value. There are people out there who need your support just as much as you need theirs. Can you find them? I suspect that you have been alone and isolated for a long time, making it impossible for you to see your worth in this situation. We need others to see our worth, and other people serve as mirrors. We can see our value reflected in their eyes.

Do you remember the first time you questioned your worth? What was happening that made you blame yourself? Can you speak to that child and reassure them that whatever was happening was not their fault? It is that child who cannot see their own worth, probably because someone treated them as if they didn't have any. However, that is just a story, not the truth. Can you find another narrative? Who might speak to your worth?

Oak Harbor, I believe that help is closer than you think. Fear wants you to believe that it's hopeless. You reached out here, so can you reach out again? Start with just one person, and that will lead you somewhere. We don't know where that somewhere is, but could it be better than staying alone? You have stopped living, but you can choose any moment to start again.

I wish you peace and hope.

Hi there,

This is a challenging situation. When you're in a relationship, it's natural to expect warmth and affection to continue. However, when these feelings fade, it can leave you feeling lonely. There could be underlying issues in the relationship or your partner may be dealing with hormonal or sexual difficulties.

Finding the right solution is subjective and entirely up to you. Allow me to ask you some questions to help guide you in exploring your next steps. Besides sexual intimacy, does your partner show love and support in other ways? Does she communicate her needs and desires to you? Does she explain what obstacles prevent sexual intimacy? By recognizing that her behavior is not personal, but rather a reflection of her own issues, you can better cope with the rejection.

In my opinion, if couples therapy hasn't proven beneficial, it might be time for your partner to take ownership of the hurdles she faces and seek help from her physician and therapist. By allowing her to take charge of the sexual aspect for a while, the pressure can be alleviated and she can focus on understanding what hampers regular sexual intimacy in your relationship. If you approach this as supporting your wife during a crisis, regardless of resolution, it can help you manage your own emotions.

Pressuring her to engage in sex may drive her further away. Has the couple's therapist helped you understand the dynamics of your relationship? Has your partner identified any specific needs that are unfulfilled? A good approach is to reciprocate her desires rather than solely focusing on sex.

It's appropriate to express to her that you cannot sustain a relationship with such limited intimacy. You need her to be honest about what she wants sexually. If that's all she wants, you're uncertain if you can accept it. However, if she desires a more fulfilling sexual connection, she needs to address the obstacles she faces. Give her some time, offer assistance, and reevaluate the situation. Observe if she seeks help to address her own issues.

From there, you will have to make a decision. I encourage you to look at the bigger picture, not just the physical aspect, when making your choice.
